We are given the sequence gm​=mϕm(−1)m+1​, where ϕ is the golden ratio (ϕ=21+5​​). We analyze the power series F(z)=∑m≥1​gm​zm.
1. Showing F(z)=ln(1+z/ϕ) on ∣z∣≤1
We substitute the definition of gm​ into the power series:
$$ F(z) = \sum_{m=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^{m+1}}{m \phi^m} z^m = \sum_{m=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-1)^{m+1}}{m} \left(\frac{z}{\phi}\right)^m $$
This is the Maclaurin series expansion for the natural logarithm, ln(1+x)=∑m=1∞​m(−1)m+1​xm, with x=z/ϕ.
$$ F(z) = \ln\left(1 + \frac{z}{\phi}\right) $$
The Maclaurin series for ln(1+x) converges when −1<x≤1. Therefore, F(z) converges when −1<z/ϕ≤1, or −ϕ<z≤ϕ. Since ϕ≈1.618, the disk ∣z∣≤1 is contained within the region of convergence, so the equality holds on this disk.
2. Proving Absolute Convergence on ∣z∣≤1
To prove absolute convergence, we examine the series of the absolute values of the terms:
$$ \sum_{m=1}^{\infty} |g_m z^m| = \sum_{m=1}^{\infty} \left|\frac{(-1)^{m+1}}{m \phi^m} z^m\right| = \sum_{m=1}^{\infty} \frac{|z|^m}{m \phi^m} $$
For ∣z∣≤1, we bound the series:
$$ \sum_{m=1}^{\infty} \frac{|z|^m}{m \phi^m} \le \sum_{m=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{m \phi^m} $$
We analyze the convergence of this bounding series using the Ratio Test. Let am​=mϕm1​.
$$ \lim_{m \to \infty} \left|\frac{a_{m+1}}{a_m}\right| = \lim_{m \to \infty} \frac{m \phi^m}{(m+1) \phi^{m+1}} = \lim_{m \to \infty} \frac{m}{m+1} \cdot \frac{1}{\phi} = \frac{1}{\phi} $$
Since ϕ>1, 1/ϕ<1. Thus, the bounding series converges. By the Comparison Test, F(z) converges absolutely for ∣z∣≤1.
3. Proving a Uniform Tail Bound
We seek a uniform bound for the remainder term RN​(z)=∑m=N+1∞​gm​zm for ∣z∣≤1.
$$ |R_N(z)| \le \sum_{m=N+1}^{\infty} \frac{|z|^m}{m \phi^m} \le \sum_{m=N+1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{m \phi^m} $$
We bound the terms by noting that m≥N+1, so 1/m≤1/(N+1):
$$ |R_N(z)| \le \frac{1}{N+1} \sum_{m=N+1}^{\infty} \left(\frac{1}{\phi}\right)^m $$
The summation is the tail of a geometric series with ratio r=1/ϕ. The sum is:
$$ \sum_{m=N+1}^{\infty} \left(\frac{1}{\phi}\right)^m = \frac{(1/\phi)^{N+1}}{1-1/\phi} $$
We use the property of the golden ratio, ϕ2=ϕ+1. Dividing by ϕ2 gives 1=1/ϕ+1/ϕ2, so 1−1/ϕ=1/ϕ2.
$$ \text{Sum} = \frac{(1/\phi)^{N+1}}{1/\phi^2} = \frac{1}{\phi^{N+1}} \cdot \phi^2 = \frac{1}{\phi^{N-1}} $$
The uniform tail bound is:
$$ |R_N(z)| \le \frac{1}{(N+1)\phi^{N-1}} $$
This bound is independent of z and approaches 0 as N→∞, demonstrating uniform convergence on ∣z∣≤1.
4. Evaluating F(1)=lnϕ
We evaluate the function at z=1 using the closed-form expression:
$$ F(1) = \ln\left(1 + \frac{1}{\phi}\right) $$
Using the property ϕ2=ϕ+1, we divide by ϕ to get ϕ=1+1/ϕ.
$$ F(1) = \ln(\phi) $$
